reviews.text:
This is one of those weird looking modern sculptures that one can see from afar but cannot take ones eyes off it to take in what it is and stands for 

It is worth seeing just to stand in awe at its size and design
We visited this area on a stroll in Barcelona and it was so nice. Really cool buildings around and nice things to look at.

I found it through my strolling in the city, this sculpture stands tall on the waterfront of the city made out of concrete and ceramic as an acknowledgment to Antoni Gaudi and Barcelona connection  for mosaic, a must see for all architecture's fans
Strange looking statue, near the Port Vell. Totally out of sync with the surrounding. If you take a stroll by the sea you'll come across it. Not a must see by any definition...

The statue is there in a busy junction near Port Vell. Infact, it has a neighbour in form of a giant statue of a lobster. What our guide told us was that the statue was erected while the construction of Olympic city began way back in the 1980's.

In a way, the piece represents the 'Face' of Barcelona. Not much here in terms of historical significance or even art perspectice. 

You will cross this. It is just there.
Great public art you'll probably see while exploring Port Vell and the surrounding area. 4.25 for the art and 2 for your need to seek this out while in Barcelona.

When the old harbor, the Port Well, was completely redeveloped at the beginning of 1990’s, new sculptures and work of arts were placed around. This 15 meters high structure, designed by Roy Lichenstein and made by Diego Delgado, was put here as one of the “letters of introduction” to the Olympic city. It is a colorful sculpture, influenced by the aesthetic if comics books and typical for the pop-art culture.

Great arty statue which we stumbled on by accident as it's on the road between the beach and La Rambla. It's not shown on free the tourist map we had so we didn't even know what it was until I looked it up on here. Great to see if you're in the area but not worth making a special trip for.
it is quirky, colourful, funny monument and you can help but smile at this odd thing. At every angle it looks different so makes for interesting photography.
I like modern art, so its very interesting like different people see Barcelona, I see it the same! very nice just to walk there different time.
Don't get me wrong, it's an interesting, colourful statue and a decent landmark if you're trying to find your way around but it's still just a statue.

A lovely sculpture sitting on Passeig Colom close to the Port Vell area. Very colourful (using the red, white, yellow & blue that Miro & Gaudi so very well publicised) and nicely placed in the middle of the road. Commissioned in 1991–1992, the Barcelona Head is a surrealist sculpture that was created by American Pop artist Roy Lichtenstein. It was created for the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Catalonia, Spain. Lovely photograph opportunities. Recommended!
